column8: Brand name Over the counter medication

column4: An abscess is a localized collection of pus that forms due to a bacterial infection, typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
column5: An abscess is a localized collection of pus that forms due to a bacterial infection, typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It appears as a swollen, red, painful lump that may feel warm to the touch. Treatment involves applying warm compresses to help it drain naturally, but larger or persistent abscesses may require medical intervention. A physician may need to drain it through a minor incision and prescribe antibiotics if thereâ€™s a spreading infection or underlying health issues. To prevent recurrence, maintaining proper hygiene and treating underlying conditions like diabetes is essential.

column4: Acne is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells, leading to blackheads, whiteheads, pimples, and, in severe cases, cysts or nodules.
column5: Acne is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells, leading to blackheads, whiteheads, pimples, and, in severe cases, cysts or nodules. It primarily affects the face, chest, back, and shoulders and is influenced by factors such as hormonal changes, genetics, diet, and stress. Treatment options vary based on severity and may include topical treatments like benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and retinoids, oral medications such as antibiotics, hormonal therapy (e.g., birth control pills), or isotretinoin for severe cases. Proper skincare, a balanced diet, and avoiding excessive touching or picking of acne can also help manage breakouts. Consulting a physician is recommended for personalized treatment.

column4: Acne comedonica (comedonal acne) is a non-inflammatory type of acne characterized by blackheads (open comedones) and whiteheads (closed comedones), usually appearing on the forehead, nose, and chin.
column5: Acne comedonica (comedonal acne) is a non-inflammatory type of acne characterized by blackheads (open comedones) and whiteheads (closed comedones), usually appearing on the forehead, nose, and chin. It results from clogged hair follicles due to excess oil, dead skin cells, and debris. Treatment focuses on unclogging pores and preventing new breakouts. Topical retinoids (like adapalene or tretinoin) are the first-line treatment, as they promote skin cell turnover. Salicylic acid and benzoyl peroxide can help exfoliate and reduce bacteria. Maintaining a gentle skincare routine with non-comedogenic products is essential. If severe, physicians may prescribe stronger retinoids or chemical peels for better management.
column8: CeraVe Acne Foaming Cleanser, Clean & Clear

column4: Acne nodulocystica, also known as nodulocystic acne, is a severe form of acne characterized by deep, inflamed nodules and cysts that can lead to scarring.
column5: Acne nodulocystica, also known as nodulocystic acne, is a severe form of acne characterized by deep, inflamed nodules and cysts that can lead to scarring. It commonly affects the face, chest, and back and is caused by a combination of excessive oil production, bacterial overgrowth (*Cutibacterium acnes*), and inflammation. Treatment typically includes oral isotretinoin, which is the most effective long-term option, along with antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline or minocycline) to reduce inflammation. In some cases, corticosteroid injections may be used for large, painful nodules. Topical treatments like retinoids and benzoyl peroxide can help prevent new lesions, and dermatological procedures such as laser therapy or chemical peels may aid in scar reduction. Consulting a physician is essential for proper management.
column8: CeraVe Acne Foaming Cleanser, Clean & Clear

column4: Acne scars are the result of deep skin damage caused by severe or persistent acne, leading to permanent textural changes such as atrophic (depressed), hypertrophic (raised), or hyperpigmented scars.
column5: Acne scars are the result of deep skin damage caused by severe or persistent acne, leading to permanent textural changes such as atrophic (depressed), hypertrophic (raised), or hyperpigmented scars. Treatment options vary depending on the scar type and severity. Common treatments include laser therapy, chemical peels, microneedling, and dermal fillers, which help stimulate collagen production and improve skin texture. For deeper scars, procedures like subcision or punch excision may be recommended. Topical treatments with retinoids or vitamin C can help with mild scarring and discoloration. Consulting a physician is essential for personalized treatment.

column4: Acne vulgaris is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells, leading to blackheads, whiteheads, pimples, and, in severe cases, cysts or nodules.
column5: Acne vulgaris is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells, leading to blackheads, whiteheads, pimples, and, in severe cases, cysts or nodules. It primarily affects the face, chest, back, and shoulders and is influenced by factors such as hormonal changes, genetics, diet, and stress. Treatment options vary based on severity and may include topical treatments like benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and retinoids, oral medications such as antibiotics, hormonal therapy (e.g., birth control pills), or isotretinoin for severe cases. Proper skincare, a balanced diet, and avoiding excessive touching or picking of acne can also help manage breakouts. Consulting a physician is recommended for personalized treatment.

column4: Actinic keratosis (AK) is a rough, scaly patch or bump on the skin caused by long-term exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun or tanning beds.
column5: Actinic keratosis (AK) is a rough, scaly patch or bump on the skin caused by long-term exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun or tanning beds. It is considered a precancerous condition, as it can develop into squamous cell carcinoma if left untreated. AKs commonly appear on sun-exposed areas like the face, ears, scalp, and hands. Treatment options include cryotherapy (freezing the lesion with liquid nitrogen), topical medications (such as 5-fluorouracil, imiquimod, or diclofenac), photodynamic therapy (PDT), and laser treatments. Preventative measures include using sunscreen, wearing protective clothing, and avoiding excessive sun exposure.

column4: Cherry angiomas are common, benign skin growths that appear as small, red to purple bumps, often developing on the trunk, arms, or legs.
column5: Cherry angiomas are common, benign skin growths that appear as small, red to purple bumps, often developing on the trunk, arms, or legs. They result from an overgrowth of tiny blood vessels (capillaries) and tend to increase with age. While cherry angiomas are harmless and usually require no treatment, some people choose to remove them for cosmetic reasons or if they bleed frequently. Treatment options include laser therapy, electrocautery (burning), cryotherapy (freezing), or shave excision, all of which should be performed by a physician.

column4: Atopic dermatitis (eczema) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that causes red, itchy, and dry skin, often triggered by allergens, irritants, or stress.
column5: Atopic dermatitis (eczema) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that causes red, itchy, and dry skin, often triggered by allergens, irritants, or stress. It commonly affects children but can persist into adulthood. Treatment focuses on moisturizing the skin with emollients, using topical corticosteroids or calcineurin inhibitors to reduce inflammation, and avoiding triggers like harsh soaps, allergens, and stress. In severe cases, antihistamines, biologic therapies (such as dupilumab), or phototherapy may be recommended. Keeping the skin barrier healthy with regular hydration and gentle skincare is essential for managing symptoms and preventing flare-ups.

column4: An atypical melanocytic lesion (atypical nevus) is an unusual mole that may share some features with melanoma but is benign.
column5: An atypical melanocytic lesion (atypical nevus) is an unusual mole that may share some features with melanoma but is benign. These lesions often have irregular borders, uneven coloring, or a larger size than common moles. While atypical nevi are not cancerous, they can indicate an increased risk of melanoma, especially if multiple are present. Treatment typically involves monitoring for changes using dermoscopy and photographic tracking. If a lesion shows concerning changesâ€”such as rapid growth, color variation, or asymmetryâ€”excision may be recommended to rule out malignancy. Regular skin checks and sun protection are essential for individuals with atypical nevi.

column4: Balanitis is an inflammation of the glans (head) of the penis, often caused by poor hygiene, infections (bacterial or fungal), irritants, or underlying conditions like diabetes.
column5: Balanitis is an inflammation of the glans (head) of the penis, often caused by poor hygiene, infections (bacterial or fungal), irritants (soaps, lotions, or latex), or underlying conditions like diabetes. Symptoms include redness, swelling, pain, itching, and sometimes discharge. Treatment depends on the causeâ€”good hygiene and avoiding irritants can help mild cases, while antifungal creams (for yeast infections), antibiotics (for bacterial infections), or steroid creams (for irritation) may be needed. If balanitis is recurrent, managing underlying conditions and, in some cases, circumcision might be considered. If symptoms persist, a physician should be consulted.

column4: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, typically caused by prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
column5: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, typically caused by prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation. It arises from the basal cells in the epidermis and usually appears as a pearly or waxy bump, a flat, scaly patch, or a sore that doesnâ€™t heal. While BCC grows slowly and rarely spreads to other parts of the body, it can cause local tissue damage if left untreated. Treatment options include surgical excision, Mohs surgery (precise layer-by-layer removal), cryotherapy (freezing the cancer cells), topical medications (such as imiquimod or 5-fluorouracil), and radiation therapy for inoperable cases. Early detection and treatment are key to preventing complications.

column4: A benign tumor is a non-cancerous growth that forms when cells divide and grow abnormally
column5: A benign tumor is a non-cancerous growth that forms when cells divide and grow abnormally but do not invade nearby tissues or spread (metastasize) to other parts of the body. These tumors usually grow slowly, have well-defined borders, and often remain localized to one area. Examples of Benign Tumors: Lipoma â€“ Fatty growth under the skin, soft and movable. Fibroma â€“ Fibrous tissue growth, common in skin and uterus (uterine fibroids). Adenoma â€“ Arises from glandular tissue (e.g., colon polyps or pituitary adenomas). Hemangioma - Growth of blood vessels, often seen as red birthmarks.

column4: Borrelia is a genus of spiral-shaped bacteria responsible for diseases such as Lyme disease (caused by Borrelia burgdorferi) and relapsing fever.
column5: Borrelia is a genus of spiral-shaped bacteria responsible for diseases such as Lyme disease (caused by Borrelia burgdorferi) and relapsing fever. These bacteria are primarily transmitted to humans through tick or lice bites. Symptoms vary but often include fever, fatigue, joint pain, and, in Lyme disease, a characteristic bullseye rash (erythema migrans). Treatment typically involves antibiotics such as doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime, with early intervention leading to better outcomes. In severe cases or neurological involvement, intravenous antibiotics like ceftriaxone may be necessary. Preventative measures include avoiding tick-infested areas, using insect repellents, and performing tick checks after outdoor activities.

column4: Chilblains (Pernio) is an inflammatory skin condition caused by repeated exposure to cold, damp conditions.
column5: Chilblains (Pernio) is an inflammatory skin condition caused by repeated exposure to cold, damp conditions. It results in red, swollen, itchy, and sometimes blistered or ulcerated patches on fingers, toes, ears, or nose. The condition occurs due to abnormal reactions of small blood vessels to cold temperatures, leading to poor circulation and localized inflammation. Treatment focuses on keeping affected areas warm and dry, avoiding sudden temperature changes, and using topical corticosteroids or soothing creams to reduce inflammation and itching. Severe cases may require medications like nifedipine, which helps improve circulation. If symptoms persist or ulcers form, medical attention is necessary.

column4: Condyloma, commonly known as genital warts, is caused by certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly types 6 and 11.
column5: Condyloma, commonly known as genital warts, is caused by certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly types 6 and 11. These warts appear as small, flesh-colored or grayish growths in the genital or anal area and can vary in size and shape. While they are often painless, they may cause itching, discomfort, or bleeding. Treatment options include topical medications (such as imiquimod, podophyllotoxin, or sinecatechins), cryotherapy (freezing the warts with liquid nitrogen), electrocautery (burning the warts off), surgical removal, and laser therapy in severe cases. HPV vaccination can help prevent infection, and practicing safe sex reduces the risk of transmission. It's essential to consult a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment.

column4: Contact dermatitis is a skin condition caused by direct contact with an irritant or allergen, leading to redness, itching, swelling, and sometimes blisters.
column5: Contact dermatitis is a skin condition caused by direct contact with an irritant or allergen, leading to redness, itching, swelling, and sometimes blisters. It can be triggered by substances like soaps, detergents, cosmetics, plants (e.g., poison ivy), or certain metals (e.g., nickel). Treatment involves identifying and avoiding the trigger, applying soothing moisturizers, and using over-the-counter hydrocortisone creams or antihistamines to reduce inflammation and itching. In severe cases, a physician may prescribe stronger corticosteroids or other medications. Keeping the skin hydrated and using gentle, fragrance-free products can help prevent future flare-ups.

column4: A dermal nevus is a type of benign mole (nevus) that originates from melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells in the skin.
column5: A dermal nevus is a type of benign mole (nevus) that originates from melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells in the skin. It typically appears as a raised, flesh-colored to brown lesion with a smooth or warty surface. These nevi are commonly found on the face, trunk, or limbs and usually develop in childhood or early adulthood. Treatment is generally not necessary unless the nevus causes cosmetic concerns, irritation, or undergoes changes suggestive of malignancy. Removal options include surgical excision, shave removal, or laser therapy, depending on the nevusâ€™s size and location. It is important to monitor any changes in color, shape, or size and consult a physician if concerns arise.

column4: Dermatitis, unspecified (dermatitis, UNS) refers to a general inflammation of the skin without a specific cause or type identified.
column5: Dermatitis, unspecified (dermatitis, UNS) refers to a general inflammation of the skin without a specific cause or type identified. It may present as redness, itching, swelling, or dryness and can result from various triggers, including allergens, irritants, or underlying conditions. Treatment focuses on symptom relief and includes moisturizing the skin, avoiding known irritants, and using anti-inflammatory medications such as topical corticosteroids or antihistamines. In some cases, lifestyle adjustments like using mild soaps and wearing loose clothing can help. If symptoms persist or worsen, a physician should be consulted for a more precise diagnosis and targeted treatment.

column4: A dermatofibroma is a common, benign skin growth that typically appears as a small, firm, slightly raised or dimpled nodule, often brown, pink, or reddish in color.
column5: A dermatofibroma is a common, benign skin growth that typically appears as a small, firm, slightly raised or dimpled nodule, often brown, pink, or reddish in color. It usually develops on the legs, arms, or trunk and is composed of fibrous tissue. Dermatofibromas are generally harmless and asymptomatic, though they may cause mild itching or tenderness. Treatment is not necessary unless the lesion is bothersome or cosmetically undesirable. If removal is desired, options include surgical excision (which may leave a scar) or cryotherapy, though freezing may not completely eliminate the growth and could lead to recurrence.

column4: Dyshidrotic eczema, also known as pompholyx, is a chronic skin condition characterized by small, itchy, fluid-filled blisters that appear on the palms, fingers, and soles of the feet.
column5: Dyshidrotic eczema, also known as pompholyx, is a chronic skin condition characterized by small, itchy, fluid-filled blisters that appear on the palms, fingers, and soles of the feet. The exact cause is unknown, but triggers include stress, allergies, excessive sweating, and exposure to irritants like nickel or cobalt. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms through the use of topical corticosteroids, antihistamines for itching, and emollients to keep the skin hydrated. In severe cases, phototherapy or immune-modulating medications may be needed. Avoiding triggers, reducing stress, and keeping hands and feet dry can help prevent flare-ups.

column4: Eczema hypostaticum, also known as stasis dermatitis, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that occurs due to poor circulation (venous insufficiency), typically affecting the lower legs.
column5: Eczema hypostaticum, also known as stasis dermatitis, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that occurs due to poor circulation (venous insufficiency), typically affecting the lower legs. It presents as red, scaly, itchy, and sometimes weeping skin, often accompanied by swelling and skin darkening (hyperpigmentation) over time. The primary treatment focuses on improving circulation, which includes leg elevation, compression therapy (if not contraindicated), and regular movement. Topical treatments like moisturizers, corticosteroid creams, and barrier-repairing ointments help reduce inflammation and prevent dryness. In cases of infection or severe inflammation, antibiotics or stronger prescription medications may be necessary. Long-term management includes controlling underlying conditions (e.g., varicose veins, heart failure) and maintaining good skin hygiene.

column4: Eczema nummularis, also known as nummular eczema or discoid eczema, is a chronic skin condition characterized by coin-shaped, itchy, inflamed patches that often appear on the arms, legs, or torso.
column5: Eczema nummularis, also known as nummular eczema or discoid eczema, is a chronic skin condition characterized by coin-shaped, itchy, inflamed patches that often appear on the arms, legs, or torso. These lesions may be dry, scaly, or ooze fluid, leading to crusting. The exact cause is unclear, but it is often linked to dry skin, allergens, irritants, and environmental factors. Treatment includes moisturizing regularly, using topical corticosteroids or calcineurin inhibitors, and avoiding triggers like harsh soaps and allergens. In severe cases, antibiotics may be needed if infection occurs, and antihistamines can help relieve itching. A physician can provide personalized management strategies.

column4: An epidermal benign cyst, commonly known as an epidermoid cyst, is a non-cancerous, slow-growing lump that forms beneath the skin.
column5: An epidermal benign cyst, commonly known as an epidermoid cyst, is a non-cancerous, slow-growing lump that forms beneath the skin. It typically develops due to the accumulation of keratin within a sac, often resulting from blocked hair follicles or skin trauma. These cysts are usually painless but can become red, swollen, or infected. Treatment isn't always necessary unless the cyst causes discomfort or infection. In such cases, options include incision and drainage, surgical excision to remove the entire cyst wall, or intralesional steroid injections to reduce inflammation. If infected, antibiotics may be prescribed. It's best to consult a physician for proper evaluation and management.

column4: Erysipelas is a bacterial skin infection, usually caused by Streptococcus bacteria, that affects the upper layers of the skin.
column5: Erysipelas is a bacterial skin infection, usually caused by Streptococcus bacteria, that affects the upper layers of the skin. It presents as a well-defined, red, swollen, and warm area, often with a raised border, typically on the legs or face. Symptoms can include fever, chills, and general malaise. Treatment involves oral or intravenous antibiotics, with penicillin being the first-line choice. In cases of allergy, alternatives like clindamycin or erythromycin may be used. Pain relievers, elevation of the affected limb, and proper wound care can also help in recovery. Prompt medical attention is necessary to prevent complications such as abscesses or sepsis.

column4: Erythema infectiosum (Fifth Disease) is a common viral infection caused by parvovirus B19, primarily affecting children.
column5: Erythema infectiosum (Fifth Disease) is a common viral infection caused by parvovirus B19, primarily affecting children. It is characterized by a "slapped-cheek" rash on the face, followed by a lacy red rash on the body. Symptoms may include mild fever, fatigue, and joint pain, especially in adults. The illness is usually mild and self-limiting, resolving on its own within one to three weeks. Treatment focuses on symptom relief, including rest, hydration, and over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen. Since it is viral, antibiotics are not effective. Those with weakened immune systems should consult a physician, as complications can arise.

column4: Folliculitis is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become inflamed due to infection, irritation, or blockage.
column5: Folliculitis is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become inflamed due to infection, irritation, or blockage. It often appears as red, itchy, or pus-filled bumps, resembling acne, and can be caused by bacteria (like Staphylococcus aureus), fungi, or friction from clothing. Mild cases usually resolve on their own, but treatment may include applying warm compresses, using antibacterial or antifungal cleansers, and avoiding tight clothing. More severe cases may require topical or oral antibiotics, antifungal medications, or corticosteroids. Keeping the skin clean and dry can help prevent future outbreaks.

column4: A furuncle, or deep folliculitis, is a painful, pus-filled bump that forms under the skin due to a bacterial infection of a hair follicle.
column5: A furuncle, or deep folliculitis, is a painful, pus-filled bump that forms under the skin due to a bacterial infection of a hair follicle, most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It often appears as a red, swollen nodule that may develop a central white or yellow head as it fills with pus. Treatment involves applying warm compresses to promote drainage, maintaining good hygiene, and avoiding squeezing the lesion to prevent spreading the infection. If the furuncle is large, persistent, or accompanied by fever, a healthcare provider may need to drain it surgically and prescribe oral antibiotics. In recurrent cases, antibacterial washes or nasal mupirocin may be recommended to reduce bacterial colonization.
column7:

column8:

Neosporin â€“ avoid if allergic

column4: Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV), typically HSV-2.
column5: Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV), typically HSV-2, though HSV-1 can also be responsible. It presents as painful blisters or sores on the genital and surrounding areas, often accompanied by itching, burning, or flu-like symptoms during outbreaks. While there is no cure, antiviral medications like acyclovir, valacyclovir, and famciclovir can help manage symptoms, reduce outbreak frequency, and lower transmission risk. Safe sex practices and communication with partners are crucial in managing and preventing the spread of the virus.
column7:

Lidocaine 5% gel/cream
Benzocaine ointments

Ibuprofen

column4: Granuloma annulare is a chronic skin condition characterized by raised, reddish or skin-colored bumps forming ring-shaped patterns.
column5: Granuloma annulare is a chronic skin condition characterized by raised, reddish or skin-colored bumps forming ring-shaped patterns, most commonly on the hands, feet, elbows, or knees. The exact cause is unknown, but it is thought to be related to immune system dysfunction and may be triggered by infections, minor skin injuries, or systemic diseases like diabetes. Treatment is often unnecessary, as the condition can resolve on its own. However, for persistent or widespread cases, corticosteroid creams, intralesional steroid injections, cryotherapy, or phototherapy may be used to reduce inflammation and promote healing. If granuloma annulare is widespread, systemic medications such as hydroxychloroquine or dapsone may be prescribed.

column4: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a contagious viral infection primarily affecting young children but can also occur in adults. It is caused by enteroviruses, most commonly the coxsackievirus.
column5: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a contagious viral infection primarily affecting young children but can also occur in adults. It is caused by enteroviruses, most commonly the coxsackievirus. HFMD is characterized by fever, sore throat, and painful sores in the mouth, along with a rash or blisters on the hands, feet, and sometimes the buttocks. The illness usually resolves within 7â€“10 days without specific treatment. Management focuses on symptom relief, including hydration, pain relief (acetaminophen or ibuprofen), and soothing mouth ulcers with cold foods or topical gels. Good hygiene and avoiding close contact with infected individuals help prevent its spread. If severe symptoms arise, a physician should be consulted.

column4: A hematoma is a localized collection of blood outside blood vessels, usually caused by trauma, injury, or surgery, leading to blood pooling under the skin, muscles, or other tissues.
column5: A hematoma is a localized collection of blood outside blood vessels, usually caused by trauma, injury, or surgery, leading to blood pooling under the skin, muscles, or other tissues. It often appears as a swollen, bruised area that may be tender or firm. Most hematomas heal on their own, but treatment includes rest, ice, compression, and elevation (R.I.C.E.) to reduce swelling and pain. Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help manage discomfort. If a hematoma is large, continues to grow, or causes significant pain, medical evaluation may be needed to drain it or rule out complications.

column4: Herpes simplex is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV), which exists in two types: HSV-1 (commonly causing oral herpes, like cold sores).
column5: Herpes simplex is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV), which exists in two types: HSV-1 (commonly causing oral herpes, like cold sores) and HSV-2 (primarily responsible for genital herpes). The virus spreads through direct contact with infected skin or bodily fluids and can remain dormant in the body, causing recurrent outbreaks triggered by stress, illness, or a weakened immune system. Treatment includes antiviral medications like acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir, which help reduce symptoms, shorten outbreaks, and lower transmission risk. While there is no cure, lifestyle adjustments, stress management, and proper hygiene can help manage the condition and reduce flare-ups.

column4: Herpes zoster (shingles) is a viral infection caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), the same virus responsible for chickenpox.
column5: Herpes zoster (shingles) is a viral infection caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), the same virus responsible for chickenpox. It typically presents as a painful, blistering rash that follows a dermatomal distribution (along a nerve path) and is often accompanied by burning, itching, or tingling sensations. The rash usually affects one side of the body and can last 2â€“4 weeks. Treatment includes antiviral medications like acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir, which are most effective when started within 72 hours of rash onset. Pain management may involve NSAIDs, acetaminophen, or even nerve pain medications like gabapentin. In severe cases, corticosteroids may be used under medical supervision. Vaccination (Shingrix) is recommended for older adults to prevent shingles and its complications, such as postherpetic neuralgia (PHN).

column4: Impetigo is a common and highly contagious bacterial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
column5: Impetigo is a common and highly contagious bacterial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. It typically appears as red sores that burst, ooze, and form honey-colored crusts, often around the nose, mouth, and hands. It spreads through direct contact with infected skin or contaminated objects. Treatment usually involves topical antibiotics like mupirocin for mild cases, while more severe infections may require oral antibiotics such as cephalexin or dicloxacillin. Keeping the affected area clean, avoiding scratching, and practicing good hygiene help prevent spread and recurrence. If symptoms worsen or persist, a physician should be consulted.
column7: Antiseptic Cleansing, Polysporin, Neosporin â€” avoid if allergic

chlorhexidine, benzalkonium chloride, Bacitracin,

column4: An insect bite occurs when an insect, such as a mosquito, flea, or spider, punctures the skin to feed or defend itself, often causing redness, swelling, itching.
column5: An insect bite occurs when an insect, such as a mosquito, flea, or spider, punctures the skin to feed or defend itself, often causing redness, swelling, itching, or pain. Most bites are harmless and resolve on their own within a few days. To treat an insect bite, wash the area with soap and water, apply a cold compress to reduce swelling, and use antihistamine creams or oral antihistamines to relieve itching. Over-the-counter pain relievers can help with discomfort. Avoid scratching to prevent infection, and if signs of severe allergic reaction (difficulty breathing, swelling of the face or throat) appear, seek medical help immediately.

column4: Intertrigo is an inflammatory skin condition that occurs in warm, moist areas where skin folds rub together, such as under the breasts, armpits, groin, or between abdominal folds.
column5: Intertrigo is an inflammatory skin condition that occurs in warm, moist areas where skin folds rub together, such as under the breasts, armpits, groin, or between abdominal folds. It appears as red, inflamed, sometimes itchy or painful patches and can become secondarily infected by bacteria or fungi. Treatment involves keeping the affected area clean, dry, and well-ventilated. Applying barrier creams, such as zinc oxide or petroleum jelly, can reduce friction, while antifungal or antibacterial creams may be necessary if an infection develops. In persistent cases, a physician may prescribe medicated powders or topical steroids to reduce inflammation.

column4: A keloid is a raised, thickened scar that extends beyond the original wound due to excessive collagen production.
column5: A keloid is a raised, thickened scar that extends beyond the original wound due to excessive collagen production. It often appears after injuries, surgeries, burns, or even minor skin trauma like acne or piercings. Keloids can be itchy, painful, or simply a cosmetic concern. Treatment options include corticosteroid injections to reduce inflammation, silicone sheets or gels to flatten the scar, cryotherapy (freezing), laser therapy, or surgical removalâ€”though surgery may risk recurrence. Pressure therapy and radiation are sometimes used for stubborn cases. Since keloids can return, early treatment and prevention (e.g., proper wound care) are key.

column4: Keratosis pilaris is a common, harmless skin condition that causes small, rough bumps on the upper arms, thighs, cheeks, or buttocks.
column5: Keratosis pilaris is a common, harmless skin condition that causes small, rough bumps on the upper arms, thighs, cheeks, or buttocks. It occurs due to the buildup of keratin, which blocks hair follicles, leading to a "chicken skin" appearance. While it is not dangerous, it can be persistent. Treatment focuses on moisturizing and exfoliating to smooth the skin. Using lotions with lactic acid, urea, salicylic acid, or glycolic acid can help remove dead skin cells. Regular exfoliation with gentle scrubs and maintaining skin hydration with thick moisturizers can improve texture. Though there is no permanent cure, consistent skincare can significantly reduce its appearance.

column4: A lentigo is a small, well-defined, pigmented spot on the skin caused by an increase in melanocytes.
column5: A lentigo is a small, well-defined, pigmented spot on the skin caused by an increase in melanocytes. It can appear as a result of sun exposure (solar lentigo) or due to genetic factors (lentigo simplex). Unlike freckles, lentigines do not fade in winter. Treatment depends on the type and cause but may include topical creams (retinoids, hydroquinone), laser therapy, cryotherapy, or chemical peels to lighten or remove the lesion. Sun protection is crucial to prevent new lesions and stop existing ones from darkening. If a lentigo changes in size, shape, or color, a physician should evaluate it to rule out malignancy.

column4: Lichen ruber planus (Lichen Planus) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the skin, mucous membranes, nails, and hair.
column5: Lichen ruber planus (Lichen Planus) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the skin, mucous membranes, nails, and hair. It presents as itchy, purple, polygonal papules, often on the wrists, ankles, lower back, and oral mucosa. The exact cause is unknown but is believed to be an immune-mediated disorder, sometimes triggered by infections, medications, or autoimmune conditions. Treatment focuses on reducing symptoms and inflammation, typically using topical corticosteroids, antihistamines for itch relief, and, in severe cases, systemic corticosteroids or immunosuppressants like cyclosporine. Phototherapy (PUVA or UVB) can also be helpful. Oral lichen planus may require corticosteroid mouthwashes or immunomodulators. Since it can be chronic and recurrent, long-term follow-up with a physician is recommended.

column4: Lichen sclerosus et atrophicus (LSA) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that primarily affects the genital and perianal regions but can appear on other parts of the body.
column5: Lichen sclerosus et atrophicus (LSA) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that primarily affects the genital and perianal regions but can appear on other parts of the body. It is more common in women, particularly postmenopausal, but can also affect men and children. The condition presents as white, thin, wrinkled patches of skin that may cause itching, pain, or discomfort, and in severe cases, lead to scarring and functional impairment. Treatment typically involves high-potency topical corticosteroids (e.g., clobetasol propionate) to reduce inflammation and prevent disease progression. Long-term management may include calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus), moisturizers, and avoidance of irritants. In cases with significant scarring, surgical intervention may be needed, particularly in men with phimosis. Regular follow-up is essential to monitor for complications, including an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma in affected areas.

column4: Livedo reticularis is a vascular skin condition characterized by a mottled, lace-like purplish discoloration of the skin, usually on the legs and arms.
column5: Livedo reticularis is a vascular skin condition characterized by a mottled, lace-like purplish discoloration of the skin, usually on the legs and arms. It results from sluggish blood flow in the capillaries, often exacerbated by cold temperatures. It can be benign (physiologic) or associated with underlying conditions such as autoimmune diseases, vasculitis, or blood clotting disorders. Treatment depends on the cause: physiologic livedo reticularis may resolve with warming, while secondary cases require addressing the underlying condition. If caused by autoimmune or vascular disorders, medications like anticoagulants, vasodilators, or immunosuppressants may be needed. A physician or vascular specialist should evaluate persistent cases.

column4: Malignant melanoma is an aggressive type of skin cancer that originates in the melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells of the skin.
column5: Malignant melanoma is an aggressive type of skin cancer that originates in the melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells of the skin. It often appears as an irregularly shaped, multicolored mole that may change in size, color, or texture. Early detection is crucial, as melanoma can spread (metastasize) to other organs if left untreated. Treatment typically involves surgical excision of the tumor, sometimes with a wide margin to ensure complete removal. In more advanced cases, treatment may include immunotherapy, targeted therapy, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy. Regular skin checks and sun protection are key to prevention and early intervention. If you suspect melanoma, seek immediate medical attention.

column4: Melasma (Chloasma) is a common skin condition characterized by dark, irregular patches, usually on the face.
column5: Melasma (Chloasma) is a common skin condition characterized by dark, irregular patches, usually on the face, particularly on the cheeks, forehead, nose, and upper lip. It is often triggered by sun exposure, hormonal changes (such as pregnancy or birth control use), and genetic predisposition. Treatment focuses on sun protection with broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30+), topical agents like hydroquinone, retinoids, azelaic acid, and kojic acid, and in some cases, dermatological procedures such as chemical peels, laser therapy, or microneedling. Managing hormonal triggers and avoiding excessive sun exposure are also key to preventing recurrence.

column4: Milia are small, white or yellowish cysts that form when keratin (a protein in the skin) becomes trapped beneath the surface.
column5: Milia are small, white or yellowish cysts that form when keratin (a protein in the skin) becomes trapped beneath the surface. They commonly appear on the face, especially around the eyes, nose, and cheeks, and are more frequent in newborns but can affect people of all ages. Milia are generally harmless and often resolve on their own. Treatment options include gentle exfoliation, retinoid creams, and chemical peels to promote skin turnover. In persistent cases, a physician can remove them using a sterile needle or laser treatment. Avoid picking or squeezing, as this can lead to irritation or infection.

column4: Miliaria, commonly known as heat rash or prickly heat, occurs when sweat glands become blocked, trapping sweat beneath the skin.
column5: Miliaria, commonly known as heat rash or prickly heat, occurs when sweat glands become blocked, trapping sweat beneath the skin. This leads to small, red, itchy bumps or blisters, often on areas prone to sweating like the neck, chest, back, and folds of the skin. It is common in hot, humid conditions and can affect both children and adults. Treatment focuses on keeping the skin cool and dry, wearing loose, breathable clothing, and avoiding excessive heat or sweating. Mild cases resolve on their own, but calamine lotion, hydrocortisone cream, or antihistamines can help relieve itching and irritation. If the rash worsens or shows signs of infection (pus, swelling, or fever), medical attention is needed.

column4: Molluscum contagiosum is a common, contagious viral skin infection caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV).
column5: Molluscum contagiosum is a common, contagious viral skin infection caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV), which leads to small, firm, dome-shaped papules with a central dimple. These lesions can appear anywhere on the body, often spreading through direct skin contact, contaminated objects, or sexual contact in adults. While molluscum contagiosum is generally harmless and self-limiting, resolving within 6-12 months, treatment may be considered for cosmetic reasons or to prevent spread. Options include cryotherapy (freezing with liquid nitrogen), curettage (scraping), topical treatments (such as imiquimod, salicylic acid, or cantharidin), and laser therapy. Keeping the skin moisturized, avoiding scratching, and maintaining good hygiene can help prevent further spread. If persistent or widespread, consulting a physician is recommended.

column4: Neurodermatitis (Lichen Simplex Chronicus) is a chronic skin condition characterized by intense itching and thickened leathery skin
column5: Neurodermatitis (Lichen Simplex Chronicus) is a chronic skin condition characterized by intense itching and thickened, leathery skin caused by repeated scratching or rubbing. It often develops in response to an initial irritant, stress, or an underlying skin condition such as eczema or psoriasis. Commonly affected areas include the neck, wrists, forearms, and ankles. Treatment focuses on breaking the itch-scratch cycle through topical corticosteroids, antihistamines, and moisturizers to reduce inflammation and itchiness. Behavioral therapy, stress management, and occlusive dressings can help prevent further scratching. In severe cases, calcineurin inhibitors or steroid injections may be prescribed. Identifying and managing triggers is crucial for long-term relief.

column4: A nevus (benign mole) is a common, non-cancerous skin growth caused by a cluster of pigmented cells (melanocytes).
column5: A nevus (benign mole) is a common, non-cancerous skin growth caused by a cluster of pigmented cells (melanocytes). These moles can appear anywhere on the body and vary in color, shape, and size. While most benign moles are harmless and do not require treatment, they should be monitored for changes in color, size, shape, or texture, which could indicate malignancy. If removal is desired for cosmetic reasons or due to irritation, treatment options include surgical excision, shave removal, or laser therapy. Always consult a physician if a mole exhibits irregular borders, rapid growth, or other suspicious changes.

column4: Pearly penile papules (PPP) are small, dome-shaped or filiform bumps that typically appear in rows around the corona of the glans penis.
column5: Pearly penile papules (PPP) are small, dome-shaped or filiform bumps that typically appear in rows around the corona of the glans penis. They are benign, non-contagious, and commonly mistaken for sexually transmitted infections (STIs). PPP occurs naturally in some men and does not require treatment. However, for cosmetic reasons, treatments like carbon dioxide (CO2) laser therapy, cryotherapy (freezing), or electrosurgery can be used to remove them. Since they pose no health risk, medical intervention is optional and should be done by a qualified physician.

column4: Perioral dermatitis is a common inflammatory skin condition that appears as a red, bumpy rash around the mouth, nose, and sometimes the eyes.
column5: Perioral dermatitis is a common inflammatory skin condition that appears as a red, bumpy rash around the mouth, nose, and sometimes the eyes. It often looks like small red papules or pustules on a background of irritated skin. The exact cause is unclear, but it can be triggered by topical steroids, skincare products, hormonal changes, or even certain toothpaste ingredients. Treatment involves discontinuing any topical steroids, switching to gentle skincare products, and sometimes using oral or topical antibiotics like doxycycline or metronidazole. Avoiding heavy creams and fluoridated toothpaste may also help. If symptoms persist, consulting a physician is recommended for tailored treatment.
column8:
Cetaphil Gentle Skin Cleanser
La Roche-Posay Toleriane Cleanser

column4: Petechiae and purpura are small, red or purple spots on the skin caused by bleeding under the skin.
column5: Petechiae and purpura are small, red or purple spots on the skin caused by bleeding under the skin. Petechiae are tiny (less than 2 mm), while purpura are larger (3 mm to 1 cm or more). They do not blanch when pressed and can result from various conditions, including infections, blood disorders, trauma, or medication side effects. Treatment depends on the underlying cause. If due to minor trauma, they may resolve on their own. However, if caused by an infection, clotting disorder, or medication reaction, medical attention is required. Serious conditions like meningococcemia or thrombocytopenia need urgent care. If you notice unexplained petechiae or purpura, especially with fever or other symptoms, seek medical help immediately.

column4: Phytophotodermatitis is a skin reaction caused by contact with plant compounds (like citrus fruits, celery, or wild parsley) followed by exposure to sunlight.
column5: Phytophotodermatitis is a skin reaction caused by contact with plant compounds (like citrus fruits, celery, or wild parsley) followed by exposure to sunlight. It results in redness, blistering, and hyperpigmentation, often appearing in streaks or drip-like patterns. The reaction is due to furocoumarins in the plants, which make the skin more sensitive to UV rays. Treatment involves washing the affected area thoroughly, avoiding further sun exposure, using cool compresses, and applying topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation. Hyperpigmentation may take weeks to fade, and using sunscreen can help prevent dark spots from worsening.

column4: Pityriasis alba is a common, benign skin condition primarily affecting children and adolescents, characterized by round or oval, scaly, hypopigmented (lighter than surrounding skin) patches.
column5: Pityriasis alba is a common, benign skin condition primarily affecting children and adolescents, characterized by round or oval, scaly, hypopigmented (lighter than surrounding skin) patches, usually on the face, arms, or upper body. It is thought to be related to mild eczema and often worsens with sun exposure due to contrast between affected and normal skin. While the exact cause is unknown, it is associated with dry skin and may be triggered by environmental factors. Treatment includes moisturizing creams to prevent dryness, mild topical corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone) for inflammation, and sunscreen to minimize contrast with surrounding skin. The condition is self-limiting and typically resolves over time without scarring.

column4: Pityriasis rosea is a common, self-limiting skin condition that typically starts with a single, large, scaly patch called a herald patch, followed by a widespread rash of smaller, pink or salmon-colored lesions.
column5: Pityriasis rosea is a common, self-limiting skin condition that typically starts with a single, large, scaly patch called a herald patch, followed by a widespread rash of smaller, pink or salmon-colored lesions, often arranged in a Christmas tree pattern on the trunk. The exact cause is unknown, but it is suspected to be linked to viral infections, particularly human herpesvirus 6 or 7. The condition usually resolves on its own within 6 to 8 weeks without scarring. Treatment is generally aimed at relieving symptoms, such as itching, which can be managed with antihistamines, topical corticosteroids, or soothing lotions like calamine. In severe cases, UVB phototherapy or oral steroids may be recommended. Staying hydrated, avoiding hot showers, and wearing loose, cotton clothing can also help ease discomfort.

column4: Pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor, is a common fungal skin infection caused by the yeast Malassezia, which disrupts normal skin pigmentation, leading to discolored patches that may be lighter or darker than the surrounding skin.
column5: Pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor, is a common fungal skin infection caused by the yeast Malassezia, which disrupts normal skin pigmentation, leading to discolored patches that may be lighter or darker than the surrounding skin. These patches often appear on the chest, back, neck, and arms and may be scaly or mildly itchy. The condition thrives in warm, humid environments and is more common in individuals with oily skin or those who sweat excessively. Treatment typically involves antifungal creams, shampoos, or lotions containing ketoconazole, selenium sulfide, or clotrimazole. In more severe cases, oral antifungal medications like fluconazole or itraconazole may be prescribed. Even after treatment, discoloration may take weeks to fade, and recurrence is common, requiring maintenance therapy in some cases.

column4: Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) is a common skin condition where darkened patches or spots appear after inflammation or injury, such as acne, eczema, burns, or insect bites.
column5: Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) is a common skin condition where darkened patches or spots appear after inflammation or injury, such as acne, eczema, burns, or insect bites. It occurs due to excess melanin production in response to skin trauma. PIH is more prevalent in darker skin tones and can persist for weeks to months. Treatment includes topical agents like hydroquinone, retinoids, vitamin C, and azelaic acid to lighten pigmentation. Chemical peels, laser therapy, and microneedling can also help. Sun protection with broad-spectrum SPF is crucial to prevent worsening pigmentation. For stubborn cases, a physician can offer customized treatments.

column4: Prurigo nodularis (PN) is a chronic skin condition characterized by intensely itchy, firm, and often hyperpigmented nodules that develop due to repeated scratching.
column5: Prurigo nodularis (PN) is a chronic skin condition characterized by intensely itchy, firm, and often hyperpigmented nodules that develop due to repeated scratching. The exact cause is unknown, but it is associated with conditions like eczema, psoriasis, diabetes, and autoimmune disorders. Treatment focuses on breaking the itch-scratch cycle and reducing inflammation. This includes topical corticosteroids, antihistamines, capsaicin cream, and calcineurin inhibitors. In severe cases, phototherapy, injectable biologics (e.g., dupilumab), or immunosuppressants may be used. Managing underlying conditions and using moisturizers to maintain skin barrier function are also crucial. physicians may recommend behavioral therapy to help reduce scratching habits.

column4: Pseudofolliculitis barbae (PFB) is a common inflammatory skin condition caused by ingrown hairs, typically affecting individuals with curly or coarse hair, especially in the beard area.
column5: Pseudofolliculitis barbae (PFB) is a common inflammatory skin condition caused by ingrown hairs, typically affecting individuals with curly or coarse hair, especially in the beard area. It occurs when hair curls back into the skin, leading to red, inflamed bumps that may resemble acne. To treat PFB, avoid close shaving and use single-blade razors or electric clippers instead of multi-blade razors. Shave in the direction of hair growth and apply a warm compress before shaving to soften hairs. Exfoliating with gentle scrubs or chemical exfoliants (like glycolic acid) can help prevent ingrown hairs. Topical treatments such as hydrocortisone, benzoyl peroxide, or retinoids may reduce inflammation. In severe cases, laser hair removal or prescription medications like topical antibiotics can be considered.

column4: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that causes rapid skin cell turnover, leading to red, scaly, and often itchy patches, commonly on the elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back.
column5: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that causes rapid skin cell turnover, leading to red, scaly, and often itchy patches, commonly on the elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back. It is not contagious and can be triggered by stress, infections, cold weather, or certain medications. Treatment options vary depending on severity and include topical corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs, moisturizers, and phototherapy for mild cases. More severe cases may require systemic treatments such as biologics or immunosuppressants like methotrexate. Lifestyle changes, including stress management and avoiding triggers, can also help manage symptoms. Consulting a physician is essential for a tailored treatment plan.

column4: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign, rapidly growing skin or mucosal lesion that appears as a red, vascular, and often bleeding nodule.
column5: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign, rapidly growing skin or mucosal lesion that appears as a red, vascular, and often bleeding nodule. It commonly occurs after minor trauma, during pregnancy, or in response to certain medications. While not dangerous, it can be bothersome due to frequent bleeding and cosmetic concerns. Treatment options include cauterization, cryotherapy, laser therapy, or surgical excision, depending on the size and location. Recurrence is possible, so complete removal is often recommended. If a lesion persists or grows rapidly, a biopsy may be needed to rule out malignancy.

column4: Rosacea is a chronic skin condition that primarily affects the face, causing redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes small, pus-filled bumps.
column5: Rosacea is a chronic skin condition that primarily affects the face, causing redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes small, pus-filled bumps. It often flares up due to triggers such as spicy foods, alcohol, stress, and extreme temperatures. While there is no cure, treatment focuses on managing symptoms. This includes using gentle skincare, avoiding triggers, and applying sunscreen daily. Medical treatments may involve topical creams (like metronidazole or azelaic acid), oral antibiotics, or laser therapy for persistent redness and blood vessels. Consulting a physician can help tailor the best treatment plan for individual cases.

column4: Scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by the Sarcoptes scabiei mite, which burrows into the skin, leading to intense itching.
column5: Scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by the Sarcoptes scabiei mite, which burrows into the skin, leading to intense itching, especially at night, and a rash with small red bumps or blisters. It spreads through direct skin-to-skin contact or shared personal items. Treatment involves prescription topical medications like permethrin cream or oral ivermectin in severe cases. It's crucial to treat all close contacts and wash clothing, bedding, and towels in hot water to prevent reinfestation. Persistent itching may continue for weeks after treatment, but antihistamines or steroid creams can help relieve symptoms.

column4: A scar is a mark left on the skin after a wound, burn, surgery, or injury has healed. It forms when the body produces collagen to repair damaged tissue.
column5: A scar is a mark left on the skin after a wound, burn, surgery, or injury has healed. It forms when the body produces collagen to repair damaged tissue. Scars can appear as raised (hypertrophic or keloid), flat, or sunken (atrophic) marks, depending on the injury and individual healing process. Treatment options include silicone sheets or gels, pressure therapy, laser treatments, microneedling, steroid injections, and surgical revision for severe cases. Over-the-counter creams with ingredients like vitamin E or onion extract may help improve appearance, while sunscreen prevents darkening. Always consult a physician for the best treatment plan.

column4: Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), commonly affecting children.
column5: Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), commonly affecting children. It typically presents with a sore throat, high fever, a bright red rash with a sandpaper-like texture, and a "strawberry" tongue. The rash usually starts on the neck and chest before spreading to other parts of the body. Treatment involves a full course of antibiotics, usually penicillin or amoxicillin, to prevent complications such as rheumatic fever. Supportive care, including fever reducers (e.g., acetaminophen), hydration, and rest, can help manage symptoms. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent serious complications.

column4: Sebaceous Glands & Fordyce Spots: Fordyce spots are small, painless, yellowish or white bumps that appear on the lips, cheeks, or genital areas.
column5: Sebaceous Glands & Fordyce Spots: Fordyce spots are small, painless, yellowish or white bumps that appear on the lips, cheeks, or genital areas. They are ectopic sebaceous glands, meaning they are oil glands that appear in unusual locations without hair follicles. These spots are harmless and non-contagious, typically requiring no treatment. However, for cosmetic concerns, treatments like laser therapy (CO2 or pulsed-dye lasers), micro-punch surgery, or topical retinoids (e.g., tretinoin) may help reduce their appearance. Always consult a physician before attempting any treatment.

column4: Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a common, chronic skin condition that causes red, scaly, and itchy patches.
column5: Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a common, chronic skin condition that causes red, scaly, and itchy patches, often affecting the scalp, face, and other oily areas of the body. It is linked to an overgrowth of Malassezia yeast and an abnormal immune response, often worsened by stress, cold weather, and hormonal changes. Treatment includes medicated shampoos containing ketoconazole, selenium sulfide, or zinc pyrithione for scalp involvement. For facial and body areas, antifungal creams, mild corticosteroids, and calcineurin inhibitors (like tacrolimus or pimecrolimus) can help reduce inflammation. Regular moisturizing and gentle cleansing can also aid in symptom control. If persistent, a physician should be consulted for stronger treatments.

column4: Seborrhoeic keratosis is a common, benign skin growth that appears as a waxy, scaly, or wart-like lesion, typically in shades of brown, black, or tan.
column5: Seborrhoeic keratosis is a common, benign skin growth that appears as a waxy, scaly, or wart-like lesion, typically in shades of brown, black, or tan. It often develops in older adults and is caused by a buildup of skin cells, though its exact cause is unknown. These growths are harmless but may become bothersome due to irritation, itching, or cosmetic concerns. Treatment is usually not necessary, but if removal is desired, options include cryotherapy (freezing with liquid nitrogen), curettage (scraping off the lesion), laser therapy, or electrocautery (burning off with electrical current). Always consult a physician to confirm the diagnosis and discuss the best treatment approach.

column4: A skin tag is a small, soft, benign growth that commonly appears in areas where the skin folds, such as the neck, armpits, eyelids, groin, and under the breasts.
column5: A skin tag is a small, soft, benign growth that commonly appears in areas where the skin folds, such as the neck, armpits, eyelids, groin, and under the breasts. They are made of collagen fibers and blood vessels surrounded by skin and are usually painless unless irritated. While skin tags are harmless, some people choose to remove them for cosmetic reasons or if they become bothersome. Treatment options include cutting (excision) with sterile scissors, freezing (cryotherapy) using liquid nitrogen, or burning (cauterization). Over-the-counter removal kits are available, but professional removal by a physician is safest to avoid infection or scarring.

column4: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a common type of skin cancer that arises from the squamous cells in the outer layer of the skin.
column5: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a common type of skin cancer that arises from the squamous cells in the outer layer of the skin. It often develops due to prolonged sun exposure and can appear as a scaly, red patch, an open sore, or a firm, wart-like growth that may crust or bleed. While SCC is usually slow-growing, it can spread to deeper tissues and other parts of the body if left untreated. Treatment options include surgical excision, Mohs surgery (for high-risk areas), cryotherapy (freezing), electrosurgery, radiation therapy, or topical medications like 5-fluorouracil for superficial cases. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent complications and ensure a good prognosis.

column4: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.
column5: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It progresses through stagesâ€”primary, secondary, latent, and tertiaryâ€”each with distinct symptoms. Early signs include painless sores (chancres) at the infection site, followed by rashes, fever, and swollen lymph nodes if untreated. In later stages, it can cause severe organ damage, including neurological and cardiovascular complications. Syphilis is treatable with antibiotics, primarily penicillin G, which is most effective in all stages. Early-stage syphilis typically requires a single injection, while later stages may need multiple doses. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications.

column4: Tinea corporis (ringworm) is a common fungal skin infection caused by dermatophytes, leading to red, scaly, and itchy ring-shaped rashes with a clearer center.
column5: Tinea corporis (ringworm) is a common fungal skin infection caused by dermatophytes, leading to red, scaly, and itchy ring-shaped rashes with a clearer center. It spreads through direct skin contact, contaminated objects, or animals. Treatment includes topical antifungal creams like clotrimazole or terbinafine, applied for 1-2 weeks after symptoms disappear. Severe or widespread infections may require oral antifungals like terbinafine or fluconazole. Keeping the skin clean, dry, and avoiding sharing personal items helps prevent recurrence. If symptoms persist or worsen, consult a physician for proper evaluation.

column4: Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis or ringworm, are common fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails caused by dermatophyte fungi.
column5: Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis or ringworm, are common fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails caused by dermatophyte fungi. These infections often appear as red, scaly, itchy patches with a ring-like appearance. Tinea can affect various body parts, such as the scalp (tinea capitis), feet (tinea pedis or athleteâ€™s foot), groin (tinea cruris or jock itch), and body (tinea corporis). Treatment typically involves topical antifungal creams like clotrimazole or terbinafine for mild cases. More extensive or resistant infections may require oral antifungal medications, such as fluconazole or griseofulvin. Keeping the affected area clean and dry is essential to prevent recurrence.

column4: Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is a skin condition characterized by red, itchy welts that appear suddenly due to an allergic reaction.
column5: Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is a skin condition characterized by red, itchy welts that appear suddenly due to an allergic reaction, stress, infections, or other triggers. The welts can vary in size and often fade within hours, though chronic urticaria can last for weeks or longer. Treatment typically involves identifying and avoiding triggers, taking antihistamines (such as cetirizine or loratadine) to reduce itching and swelling, and using cool compresses to soothe the skin. In severe cases, physicians may prescribe corticosteroids or biologic therapies like omalizumab. If symptoms persist or involve breathing difficulties, immediate medical attention is necessary.

column4: Vasculitis is an inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause them to thicken, weaken, narrow, or scar, leading to reduced blood flow and potential organ damage.
column5: Vasculitis is an inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause them to thicken, weaken, narrow, or scar, leading to reduced blood flow and potential organ damage. It can affect various parts of the body and may result from infections, autoimmune disorders, or unknown causes. Symptoms vary based on the type and severity but often include skin rashes, fever, fatigue, muscle pain, and nerve issues. Treatment depends on the underlying cause and severity. Mild cases may require anti-inflammatory medications like corticosteroids, while more severe forms may need immunosuppressants, biologics, or treatments targeting the root condition. A physicianâ€™s evaluation is essential for proper management.

column4: Verruca vulgaris (common warts) are small, rough, and raised skin growths caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), commonly appearing on the hands, fingers, and knees.
column5: Verruca vulgaris (common warts) are small, rough, and raised skin growths caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), commonly appearing on the hands, fingers, and knees. They spread through direct contact or contaminated surfaces and are more common in children and those with weakened immune systems. Treatment options include salicylic acid (over-the-counter treatments that gradually remove the wart), cryotherapy (freezing with liquid nitrogen), and electrosurgery or laser therapy for stubborn cases. In some cases, warts resolve on their own over time, but persistent or painful warts may require professional medical intervention.
column11: Do not pick, cover if needed

column4: Viral exanthema refers to a widespread skin rash caused by a viral infection, often accompanied by fever and other systemic symptoms.
column5: Viral exanthema refers to a widespread skin rash caused by a viral infection, often accompanied by fever and other systemic symptoms. Common causes include measles, rubella, roseola, and certain enteroviruses. The rash usually appears as red or pink maculopapular lesions and may be itchy or non-itchy. Treatment focuses on supportive care, as the rash typically resolves on its own. Management includes hydration, fever control with acetaminophen or ibuprofen, and soothing skin care with moisturizers or antihistamines for itch relief. If symptoms persist or worsen, medical evaluation is recommended.

column4: Vitiligo is a chronic skin condition characterized by the loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes), leading to white patches on the skin.
column5: Vitiligo is a chronic skin condition characterized by the loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes), leading to white patches on the skin. It can affect any part of the body, including the face, hands, and even hair. The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to be an autoimmune disorder. Treatment options aim to restore pigmentation and slow progression, including topical corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, phototherapy (narrowband UVB), and in some cases, surgical treatments like melanocyte transplants. Cosmetic camouflage and depigmentation therapy (for widespread vitiligo) are also options. While there is no definitive cure, early intervention can help manage the condition effectively.
